[h1]Спасибо, Steampipe... -_-[/h1]
Несколько лет назад я проходил HL:S и через него начинал знакомство с первой частью. У меня так интересно вышло что я сначала узнал про Garry's Mod, через него позже о HL2, и затем о HL, предпочтение отдал именно версии на Source.

Короче, когда-то всё работало как часы, но вышло обновление Source в 2013 году, тот самый проклятый Steampipe из-за которого перестали работать 90% модов для HL2 до 2013 года, но здесь картина совсем печальная. Совсем, да.

Просто сплошная куча багов, странные отражения на оружиях, учёные которые левитируют над креслами, сломанные хитбоксы у вертолётов, мешанина с звуками и текстурами из HL2 - список можно продолжать бесконечно, но смысла нет. Это не играбельный мусор который должен быть забыт как страшный сон.

Возможно сейчас починить некоторые баги или банально установить старую версию, но оно вам надо? Лучше играйте в оригинал, багов там намного меньше и поддержка модов присутствует.

[b]Итог[/b]
Я не знаю что оно забыло у меня в библиотеке, но оно точно подлежит сожжению и уничтожению. Стыдно конечно что VALVE будто забыли о существовании этой версии, лучше-бы вырезали её и не продавали такой брак, люди ведь ещё деньги тратят и не подозревают как всё плохо.

Оценку ставить не буду, сами понимаете что всё здесь печально...

Trying to decide which version of Half-Life to play for the first time in 2018, was not without some careful consideration.  Usually in situations like this I favor remastered versions of classic titles due to the upgrades and modern conveniences they provide, but even in this case you have at least a couple of options with Half-Life.  The [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362890/Black_Mesa/]Black Mesa[/url] remake looks absolutely [i]gorgeous[/i], but still lacks the final Xen levels.  So with this logic in mind I opted for the Source version of the game.  Before we talk about my experience specifically regarding the Half-Life: Source port, I'd like to discuss some of my impressions of Half-Life in general.

It's easy to see the ways in which this game is considered to be a landmark title.  Half-Life is a masterwork of "show-me-don't-tell-me" narrative structure in gaming.  There are no cut-scenes in Half-Life, no immersion breaking quicktime segments, no lengthy hand holding moments of character exposition in which the plot is explained to you.  Any and all plot advancement takes place within the game engine itself.  And yet you never feel lost in terms of the events unfolding.  The trick of course is that Half-Life makes great use of scripted events for the purpose of plot exposition.  At any given moment in the game there are often several events unfolding around you.  Scientists and security guards fight a losing battle against the alien invasion.  Marines engage the enemy in their own firefights.  And as the player you have the option to become an active participant in these events or simply remain a passive observer.  The cumulative effect of this narrative technique is that Half-Life feels immersive and cinematic, even though it never relies on a generic toolbox of 'cinematic elements' like we so often see in modern games of this type.  Half-Life pulls off the rare feat of feeling both cinematic [i]and[/i] immersive.

The gameplay and control aspects are both excellent for the most part.  Everything feels quick, highly responsive and tight.  I'm not sure Half-Life really broke new ground in this regard, but it's still among the best 'feeling' FPS games of its time.  The shooting mechanics are fun, solid feeling, and the wide variety of assorted weaponry gives the player several options of play style.  If you prefer to charge in head first, guns blazing there are weapons to support that.  If you'd rather proceed with caution using traps and environmental elements to your advantage, there are weapons to support that too.  And while there's not a [i]massive[/i] number of enemy types, there are certainly enough to necessitate a variety of strategies.  If there's one gameplay aspect where the game falters just a bit it's in the first person platforming segments.  While it's certainly possible that I just need to 'git gud' at the platforming segments, Half-Life doesn't feel as good or precise as … Portal to draw one example from the Valve stable.  This is the only aspect of Half-Life in which you can occasionally feel like you're fighting against the controls rather than being fully immersed in the game.

So let's talk just a little bit about the Source port of Half-Life.  It doesn't have … the [i]best[/i] reputation.  And unfortunately that reputation is at least partly warranted.  It's just that some aspects of the game lack the amount of polish one might expect especially when we consider that this is a Valve developed game.  Most weapons are soundless during the reload animations.  Graphical glitches run the gamut from minor to almost game breaking in certain areas.  I almost couldn't finish the 'Residue Processing' level due to the fact that the world kept on dissolving into a psychedelic rainbow nightmare.  Coupled with the fact that this level requires more platforming than any other level, it was a significant issue.  At least one other level exhibited similar major graphical glitches though not for as long or egregiously.  These are moments of severe incongruity in an otherwise fantastic game.  It just seems unfortunate that Valve has never bothered to address the issues with this port.

In hindsight I might have gone with the original release of Half-Life and just applied a high-res graphics mod, but I rather doubt that it would look as nice as Half Life: Source.  Because that's the thing; Half Life: Source looks really nice 95% percent of the time.  It's just that the experience is brought down by infrequent but significant glitches.  If you can look past the occasional glitch, you'll find a lot to love in Half Life: Source.  Half-Life is still a stunning achievement in gaming even all these years later.  But if glitches like these are going to ruin the experience for you, then your best bet will likely be waiting for the final (eventual) release of Black Mesa, or alternately simply loading up the original release.

[h1]Зачем Valve выпустили эту игру?[/h1]

Все очень просто - захотели показать, на что способен их новый на тот момент движок, ведь по сути это первая игра, которая на нем вышла (даже Half-Life 2 вышла позже Counter-Strike: Source). И клали они болт на все остальное, главное портировать все элементы игры и запихнуть на новый движок. Единственное хорошо, что карты от Source хорошо поддаются декомпилировании, благодаря чему можно сделать полноценные исходники карт для оригинальной игры.

Если вы бомж, который не желает играть в мультиплеер, или угараете над тем, как весело падают низкополигональные "монстры", смело покупайте это, но помните, там даже субтитров для диалогов нет

自从买了V社大包，半条命系列一直躺在库里长灰。
之前从来没有玩过半条命任何一部作品，一直看评测觉得剧情应该不错。
最近有了些零散的时间，通关了《半条命：起源》。

《半条命：起源》（以下称：起源）是V社在2004年用自主研制的“起源”引擎重新制作的《半条命》的重置版，在贴图和水面效果上有了很大提升。整个游戏讲述了黑山公司的雇员：戈登•弗里曼博士，在一次科学事故之后，与黑山公司、政府军、外星生物战斗的故事，整个游戏采用第一人称视角。
在《半条命》当时发售的时候，确实轰动一时。G胖在前有德军总部、毁灭战士、雷神之锤的时候，开发出一部以气氛和剧情为主的射击游戏，玩家们化身戈登•弗里曼在黑山公司的地底迷宫消灭各种外星怪物。
即使放在现在看来，《半条命》在关卡设置、剧情安排、难易度平衡上都实属上乘之作。《半条命》确实开创了FPS史上的里程碑。

十分钟下完了游戏，进游戏，开场主角在一辆驶向黑山公司内部的列车上，这车组组开了5分钟，后来想想，为什么要设置这样的开场，用5分钟的强制动画让玩家有一种被困的感觉，在没有任务提示的情况下，这样设计就给玩家一个终极提示“逃出这个地方”。

个人认为半条命的难度比较高，打了10个小时才通关，这还是在SL大法的辅助下。

陆战队队员的血太厚了，你们是吃什么长大的…...后来发现用弩箭能一箭一个。

最开始，猎头蟹的确给我留下了阴影，后来发现这小怪物还挺萌的。

游戏里需要跑酷的地方是我用尸体堆过去的，不知道为什么，跑步的时候按W键，人物会滑行一段距离。后来想想，CS也存在同样的问题，可能是引擎的原因吧，这样真的很真实。

《半条命》比起现在一路突突过去的FPS，真的好太多。

Сюжета в игре толком нет, только в начале, катсцена в середине и намек на 2 часть в конце, а дальше понимай как хочешь, легче вики почитать ( да даже в той самой википедии описано начало и конец, ну и что происходило в главах по пунктам ). After using my old CD codes from Half-Life Platinum that I bought three computers ago to download Steam versions of all the games (Half-Life, Blue Shift, Counterstrike), I decided to give the HL Source version a try, since it was on sale. Boy, am I ever glad I did. I played Half-Life not too long ago on my old Win 7 laptop and the game itself was every bit as fun as I remembered it. 

But when trying to play HL on my Win 10 laptop, it was a little creaky and laggy, and it didn't work well with my controller and keyboard emulator. HL Source solved all that, and brightened up the game's look considerably. So far I haven't experienced any of the glitches people are talking about, so I'll keep my fingers crossed. The only minor problem I've had is that the controls are hypersensitive, so it takes me a few minutes to get acclimated to it and lighten up my touch, especially after playing other games.

Addendum to review: I stopped playing this version in the Blast Pit chapter, when the tentacle monster's hits just passed right through me, causing no damage. What I remembered as a very tense encounter guaranteed to kill me several times as I lobbed grenades to distract the beast was utterly ruined by being able to calmly and blithely ignore the tentacle beast as I walked calmly from one level to the next.

I might go back, IDK. I played regular HL for a while, but the controls were so hyper-sensitive, even with settings turned all the way down, that it caused me to die repeatedly and unnecessarily. I finally gave up and moved on to replaying HL2.

Is this the definitive version of Half Life?

Nah.  I mean the updated models look good if you enable them...but guess what?  the scripts for weapons are fucked up and it doesn't play reloading sounds.

It's like an amature mistake you'd find 10 pages in on Mod DB.com or something.  Embarrassing.

So fuck the HD pack i guess.  I mean you could go through and download a fix for it, but nah.

Get to Blast Pit and guess what, for some reason Gorden is an intangible force of pure will when faced with the green tentacle beast..you could just walk right through it.  What the fuck??  I mean it's not game breaking but it sure is stupid feeling coming across such a bug.

Is really any / all of this worth having corpses rag doll when they die?  Absolutely not.  Besides, running up and gibbing dead bodies is one of the best cathartic things about the first Half Life.  A head crab takes a nibble of you?  I mean it didn't hurt much, but that little Bastards gonna get it...SPLAT.  In this version you get no such satisfaction.

So just play the orginal game.  and the two expansions because they're cool too.

still gotta recommend it though, it's the game PCXL gave an 11/10 and for good reason.  It still rules.

Half-Life: Source ist, wie der Name bereits vermuten lässt, nichts weiter als ein Port des Originalspiels auf die neuere Source-Engine von Valve, die auch in Half-Life 2 und vielen weiteren späteren Spielen Anwendung fand. Das resultiert darin, dass das Spiel im Großen und Ganzen dieselbe Erfahrung bietet, aber es gibt auch den einen oder anderen kleinen Unterschied:

[list]
[*] Ragdoll-Physik für die Körper von toten Gegnern
[*] Verbesserungen der Lichteffekte (merklich der Taschenlampe)
[*] besser anzusehende Wasser-Texturen (wie in Half-Life 2)
[*] verbesserte Partikeleffekte wie Blut oder Einschusslöcher in Wänden.
[/list]
 
Weiter gibt es auch noch minimale grafische Unterschiede wie etwa, dass das Sturmgewehr (M16A4) durch eine SMG (MP5) ersetzt wurde oder dass die SPAS-Shotgun nun ein leicht anderes 3D-Modell hat.
 
Leider hat das "Upgrade" auch den einen oder anderen grafischen Bug mit sich gebracht, beispielsweise merkwürdige und höchst störende grafische Fehler in Kapitel 10 (konnte ich beheben indem ich MultiCore-Rendering ausgeschaltet habe in den Optionen) oder sehr nerviges Flackern der Himmelstexturen in einigen Abschnitten an der Oberfläche (hier habe ich noch keine Lösung gefunden).

Weiter gibt es häufiger Abschnitte im Spiel, an denen sich die KI absolut überhaupt nicht bewegt und nur starr herumsteht. Das gilt besonders für einige der Aliens.

[h1][b]Fazit[/b][/h1]

Half-Life ist ein absolut empfehlenswertes Spiel, daran besteht kein Zweifel. Half-Life: Source jedoch ist als alleinstehender Kauf nicht zu empfehlen, da man durch das Upgrade der Source Engine nicht von merklichen Verbesserungen profitieren kann, dafür aber eine ganze Reihe von nervigen Bugs dazubekommt.

Wer ein wirkliches "Upgrade" sucht, wird wohl eher bei Black Mesa fündig werden.

Half Life FUE un gran juego en su tiempo y aunque aun es jugable a dias de hoy se queda muy corto a mi parecer. Fuera de una pauta mas enfocada en un Half Life original tal como salio en su tiempo y centrandonos en esta "remasterizacion" solo me queda una palabra: ASQUEROSO. 
Es bueno a su modo, es Half Life despues de todo, pero esto es una BURLA a los fans de la saga de Half Life. Es triste ver que la unica buena remasterizacion venga hecha por fans (Black Mesa) ya que demuestra un desamor no solo a la saga por parte de Valve si no una falta de respeto a los fans. Veo muchos nostalfag adulando esta entrega en si, la Source, siendo que es simplemente el juego original "traspasado" al motor source. Escuchando algo como: "Es Half Life pero pasado a Source" yo me imagino algo semejante a lo que paso con Counter Strike Source, la cual fue una gran entrega remasterizada de forma real a lo todo lo que este motor grafico tiene que ofrecer realmente. La pregunta que vendra es: ¿Que tan vistoso es graficamente esta remasterizacion? y la respuesta es: NADA. Mas brillo en algunas superficies y en NPC's, agua realista (la cual desentona con los graficos de los 90's) y ragdoll. Decepcionante Valve, decepcionante...

Si esperas una version remasterizada de Half Life echo con todo lo que el motor Source puede ofrecer realmente: NO LO COMPRES

Si esperas un Half Life con todo lo ya mencionado: No soy quien para decir en que desperdicias tu dinero...
